title: Tuesday, 4th September 2018
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas Yay!!! it's alive
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Hi, good morning, hey there, hello.

Soundbuy Morning
A. M. Morning all.
BE11:04am

It's the first day of proper news post the summer holidays, yet I'm a bit unsure where to start.

BE11:04am

There's here, I guess.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

A. M. (A small query on yesterday's crypto story -- not making light of the bounty hunters' complaint, but isn't it a bit of a pot/kettle situation?)
BE11:05am

Select committee meeting today to try and clarify whether he's staying or going.

Blank canvas some views from either side of the page on the death spiral of WPP?
Excel Developer Biggest news of yesterday didn't happen. Germany's Target2 balance was trending towards 1 trillion euros: 902bln, 956bln, 976bln. . But yesterday's release showed it dropping to 913bln.
BE11:06am

Sort of like when the backing singers would walk James Brown off stage, only for him to shrug off his cloak and start up again.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Except ... you know .... not like that at all.

Excel Developer http://sdw.ecb.europa.eu/reports.do?node=1000004859
Flaneur The Rentier-in-Chief.... should be made to walk the plank...
BE11:07am

The FT's leader writers have a view: https://www.ft.com...-8d14-6f049d06439c

Soundbuy James Brown minus the charisma..
BE11:07am

Leading the BoE should not, however, be treated as an acceptable second best. As with the highly paid “star” international managers now dotted across top British and European football clubs, there is a danger that Mr Carney becomes bigger than the institution he heads.

Should the governor confirm his willingness to postpone his departure, therefore, MPs and the government should thank him for that offer, and for his achievements to date. But they should not feel any obligation to accept. The Treasury should take a clear-headed view of options and candidates. If the current governor is the best person for the job until 2020, this is for the government, not for Mr Carney, to decide.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

.... hm. One could argue that the BOE's more Leeds United than Barcelona these days ......

Excel Developer Why discuss Carney? What would a different Governor do differently? They all have a strict mandate to follow, no?
Tom Dalgleish Why james brown
Flaneur I wonder how much of this is bait for Rees-Mogg rather than actual actualité?
Lemmy Who would Corbyn/MacDonnell want to appoint?
Excel Developer Ah yes, as @Flaneur points out Eurosceptics are out to get him.
BE11:10am

.... Anyway, there's a Brexit London house price thing to go up shortly on the main blog from Jamie and I won't pre-empt that by repeating it here. Let's get on with some stocks fun.

undefined
11:10 am
BE11:10am

WPP, then.

WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,198, down 78.5 (-6.15%), High: 1,231, Low: 1,167, Volume: 4.04m
mosschops Adam Tooze was on Talking Politics podcast the other day talking about his new book on the financial crisis and said that the largest question in British politics at the moment possibly is who replaces Carney
BE11:11am

Meet the new boss. Same as the old boss, except paid ~90% less.

Shinshin @excel agreed. It's a strict mandate, the key decisions are made by committee, and there are legions of technical exerts toiling away producing analyses. None fof that changes with a new governor. It could be any faceless person.
Shinshin Not saying htat Andrew Bailey is faceless of course.
11:11 am
BE11:12am

As well as other differences, which the lawyer won't let me mention.

BE11:12am

So. Issue here is margin guidance nudged down.

GBKrona Hola
BE11:13am

H1's in line, more or less. Organic net sales growth was 0.3%

Excel Developer @Shinshin: thanks.
Electric Dragon Janet Yellen is available ;)
cheeckychappy How about some dinner party live?
11:14 am
BE11:14am

And PBIT margin back to 13.3% from 13.8% a year ago. But then, when there's a lot going into the "miscellaneous costs" column, that kind of thing will happen.

Tour Eiffel Any comments on ALFA LN? Another negatively received set of results...
Tom Dalgleish Someone told me that UK injunctions are worldwide too. Thats a stretch isnt it?
BE11:15am

Turning to MOST to summarise the guidance cut:

Electric Dragon @BE possibly a bad analogy given that the current Leeds manager is Marco Bielsa (the Mark Carney of football management)
BE11:15am

The guidance is maintained on sales and lowered on margin. WPP says that July organic net sales growth is up 0.4% giving 0.3% growth after 7 months. It now looks for organic net sales growth similar to the first half at 0.4% - ahead of its previous flat expectation.
The full year headline PBIT margin is now targeted to be similar to the first half decline of 40bps like-for-like. This was previously targeted at flat. Fed through mechanically this is equivalent to a downgrade of around 3% at the earnings level which would take consensus to c114p. It may feed worries that new management is willing to rebase the margin.

Tom Dalgleish And thats since Spycatcher was found not to be injuncted elsewhere
Excel Developer @Tom: I don't think the premise is true. USA media can and have named persons of interest who have used a UK privacy injunction. Not giving examples for legal reasons.
Electric Dragon typo: Marcelo not Marco
chad_john Yes, the US media recently outed someone with a UK superinjunction.
chad_john (allegedly)
Manxish Morning each
Tom Dalgleish Thanks Excel. After all what was the National Inquirer for?
11:17 am
BE11:18am

That's the gist here, Forecasts aren't really moving dramatically, but the new guy seems willing to cut already.

BE11:18am

And with Mark Read delivering a strategic review by the end of the year, there's a considerable kitchen-sink risk.

BE11:18am

Here's Caz.

Excel Developer your welcome.
11:18 am
BE11:19am

We upgrade our 2018 organic growth from 0% to 0.3% and now assume a
50 basis point reduction in margin to 16.8% vs our prior assumption of flat.
This is largely offset by an FX benefit and slightly lower interest and tax and our EPS falls by 1% to 117.5p (cons 117.4p). We continue to assume 1%
organic growth in 2019 (and c1.7% growth in the medium term) but cut our
2019 margin by a further 50 basis points to reflect growth investment. We
also factor in £350m of restructuring charges across 2019/20 for
streamlining/re-organisation. We assume margins then see some recovery
from 16.3% to 17% over the following four years. Our 2019E EPS falls 2%
to 122p (cons 122p) and is broadly unchanged in the medium term. Our
DCF-based valuation of 1620p remains unchanged (8.4% and 1.1% terminal
growth)

BE11:19am

They're buyers.

BE11:19am

WPP trades on c10x downgraded 2019E EPS and
offers five-year (organic) revenue, PBIT, EPS growth of 1.7%, 5% and 7.6%
respectively and a dividend yield of c4.5%. Our DCF-based PT of 1620p
remains unchanged. The current share price broadly discounts no growth,
ever, which, in our view, is too conservative.

Excel Developer Can we take stock of global markets now that AV holidays and Labor day out the way? US Dollar swoon has passed, USTs 2s10s spread touched 20bps but now ~23bps. S&P500s record highs.
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Just scratching through sellside to find anything else interesting on WPP, and coming up lacking.

Tom Dalgleish Excel Im not not into macro please lead the way
BE11:22am

We cut our 12-month price target by c.1% to 1423p, mainly reflecting our lower EPS estimates. Following recent share price strength (+7% over the last month), we believe the weaker margin outlook and the strategy update being slightly pushed back will likely weigh on the shares today.
1H18 net sales of £6,149 mn (-3.6% yoy) came in broadly in line with expectations with FX/M&A contributing -4.7%1.1% (GS: -4.3%+0.9%). 1H EBITA of £821m (13.3% margins) was 4% below GSe and 3% below consensus due to lower
associate contribution, geographic/ function mix and reinvestments. However, diluted headline EPS of 42.6p was broadly in line with expectations owing to lower interest cost and tax rate.

Soundbuy @ Excel Developer - what does that add up to?
BE11:23am

That's Goldman. And deeply dull.

pancakes or waffles @Soundbuy - 42
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Though given WPP's recent press, perhaps "deeply dull" is the best they can hope for.

undefined
Excel Developer US stocks will rally through to January. USTs 2s10s may drop below 0 next year and presage a recession in 2019. Buy US stocks!
Excel Developer (and sell later before the recession hits)
Shinshin Flow of ad cash to Goog / fbook / etc is unabated though ? How is WPP anything other than a managed decline ?
Cracklenpop @Excel Developer S&P 500 a buy, at least til the mid-terms...
BE11:25am

@Excel, we do a lot of broad-sweep macro over here: https://www.ft.com/markets

Soundbuy :)
11:25 am
BE11:25am

....... and most days I find it a bit pointless to add to the collection.

Soundbuy Cheers...............
Excel Developer @Cracklenpop: good point about mid terms, I like the Democrats but the markets don't. If Democratss win control of HoR expect some softness but the period in the run up to Christmas is traditionally strong for stocks ("Santa Claus rally").
BE11:26am

Let me see what we have in terms of strat rattling around though. There's Credit Suisse updating its S&P target .......

BE11:27am

Over the past year, profits have surpassed expectations on tax benefits, a
strong economy, buoyant commodity prices and robust Tech results. While the market has advanced 8.5% year-to-date, stock prices have lagged EPS
growth, leaving equities 1.5x multiple points cheaper than at the start of 2018.

Excel Developer @Bryce: but can we have a counterpart "chat room" ? (and then I'll leave you in peace)
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Our [S&P500] 2019 price target of 3,350 implies an 11.4% annualized advance over the next 16 months. We expect EPS growth to decelerate from 21.5% in 2018 to 7.7% in 2019, largely the result of fading tax impacts, and is in-line with historical averages. In the absence of recessionary risks, multiples tend to
expand throughout the cycle, including its latter stages. We see P/Es returning to their year-end 2017 levels.

BE11:28am

... but ........

BE11:28am

The next 16-months will be particularly tricky for investors, with the threat of yield curve inversion, potentially disruptive midterm elections, and continued Fed tightening. Despite these headline risks, we believe that solid economic/EPS growth and benign recessionary risks will be sufficient to propel the market higher.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

(@Excel: it's over here: https://ftalphavil...com/longroom/home)

Tommy Rock ValueAct have declared a 5% stake in Horizon Discovery. Surprised the stock has not moved more.
BE11:30am

Otherwise, there's a Barclays strat update that doesn't say very much .....

BE11:30am

We initiated coverage on European Equity Strategy in July, with a Marketweight recommendation on Banks. We stick to it and remain unexcited about the medium-term prospects for the sector. However, we find Banks' recent sharp underperformance exaggerated and see a potential for a short-term bounce.

Tom Dalgleish @Excel, in my research Democrat Presidents reside over stronger stock markets by a significant margin where Republicans let it rip either way. So I assume you mean Dem HoR control
Excel Developer *sigh* The Long Room is not a chat room, I might have to build my own, but who will turn up?
11:32 am
BE11:32am

.... and a UBS ready reckoner for where we are.

BE11:32am

Despite an eventful 2018, US equity markets have surpassed their all-time highs and 100-day trailing realized volatility is once again below 10%. We remain generally positive on risk/reward thanks to solid growth, stable rates and spreads, and prospects for a weaker USD but identify 5 sources of market risk catalysts through year-end.

BE11:33am

Macro catalysts: data, trade, election, FOMC, and earnings
Our Economists expect a 10% tariff on $200 bn of China imports will drive a growth slowdown in 4Q and lead the FOMC to hike just 1 time before year-end while Evidence Lab Macro's growth signal creates some tactical risk from lower ISM and firmer inflation. On the plus side, there is a low bar for 3Q earnings but trade and monetary policy rhetoric in the run-up to 6-Nov midterm elections may increase risk premium.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Spotlight: options price modest downside risks ahead poor seasonal period The September to November period is seasonally higher volatility and lower return. Implied volatility is fairly attractive given the magnitude of upcoming events but skew is elevated and the VIX term structure shows nearly 2x the normal premium in the front of the curve. Options price +-0.9% breakeven through ISM, payrolls and the tariff announcement and +-2% to the end of September including the FOMC and CPI.

Excel Developer @Tom: I didn't know that.
BE11:33am

They're long Long S&P 500 28-Sep straddles, in case you care.

BE11:34am

We recommend buying the SPX 28-Sep 2900 straddle for $57.4 (2%) that captures the FOMC, ISM, CPI, payrolls, retail sales, and expected trade/election headlines. The absolute level of implied volatility is muted and the market has moved by about 50 bps on average to each ISM and Payrolls report over the past 2 years.

Tom Dalgleish @Excel is true. Dems keep the credit flowing.
Soundbuy @Excel Developer - offer free beer.........
11:35 am
BE11:35am

They're also Long Spain Equity, Long Europe (SX5E) vs. Short US
(SPX), Long Nikkei (as in the index), Long Sweden Banks, and Long DM Info Tech vs. Short EM Info Tech

sprout most bonkers macro piece today is from MS - massive upside to European asset prices as a long term buy on the basis of more likely progress towards fiscal integration than the market thinks - but only when EU pushed that way by the next crisis. So why buy now, duh??
Soundbuy Argentina - who's exposed there...........?
Tom Dalgleish Thats a lot of mind warp for 50bps
BE11:36am

Exciting, huh. I bloody love macro corner.

undefined
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Opp, deal on the tape.

BE11:37am

Transocean buying Ocean Rig, $2.7bn deal value including debt.

DRichi @Soundbuy- Me unfortunately....
GBKrona any idea why housebuilders being thrashed today, despite Redrow's good results?
Tom Dalgleish Nigel Farage is in Oz for a week commanding $250 a ticket
BE11:38am

Greece-based maker of semi-submersible rigs.

sprout GBK - speculation right to buy will be scrapped or at least wound down.
Flaneur @sprout - Do you mean help to buy?
sprout yes, sorry.
Soundbuy HTB - current programme beyond 2018?? Hmmm..............described on twitter this am. as throwing Kerosene on a fire.....
11:39 am
BE11:39am

Peers would be ........ few Norway based companies, maybe. Nothing much over here.

GBKrona @Sprout - thanks - whats the source?
undefined
Tom Dalgleish Transocean which sleeved BP but omitted the same on the Deepwater Horizon
BE11:40am

On housebuilders, let's get the Redrow numbers out of the way.

sprout Brokers commenting on a piece in the DT.
11:40 am
Redrow PLC (RDW:LSE): Last: 548.50, down 8 (-1.44%), High: 570.50, Low: 546.50, Volume: 999.35k
BE11:41am

They're okay on slightly better than expected volumes ....

BE11:41am

... current trading is fine but no fresh guidance.

Soundbuy Michelmersh.........fine results (even with acquisition)........only up a tad........
GBKrona thanks - just spotted HTB speculation in he Independent too:https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/help-to-buy-housing-scheme-wealthy-household-government-cut-conservative-a8519516.html
11:42 am
BE11:42am

Canaccord can summarise.

BE11:43am

A strong set of results, around +5% ahead of expectations at the PBT level. The balance sheet was also stronger than expected with net cash of £63m, with a strong +65% increase in the dividend. Recent trading and order book comments are reassuring with revenue flat over the last nine weeks; implies volumes slightly down but this is more reflective of a normal quieter summer trading period compared to stronger recent years. It looks like management remains confident of its FY2020 £430m PBT target; with the macro uncertainties around Brexit and Help to Buy, there is clearly no reason to change this at this point but we would not be surprised to see FY2019E consensus PBT edge up +1-3% to c.£400m. Given the strong growth in net assets combined with an attractive well covered dividend, we continue to believe the share looks the most attractive in the sector. The group continues to deliver strongly and looks set to continue to deliver in line with its guidance to FY 2020, supported by a strong land bank and balance sheet, assuming the market holds up as expected.

BE11:44am

(@GBKrona: please don't link to the Independent. It just ripped off the Telegraph speculation without even having the good grace to include a link out.)

11:44 am
BE11:44am

(I remember when the Independent was a newspaper. Alas ...)

GBKrona @BE - sorry, didn't know that
Flaneur I understand theres some consternation in the Tory grassroots about 'govt subsidies' while the upper echelons have their eyes firmly on the corporate donation side of things.
BE11:45am

And Jefferies, briefly.

BE11:45am

Conclusion: We see no reason in today's Full-Year results why the price of Redrow's shares has fallen by 15% since the start of the year. Record volumes, record profits and, looking forward, a record order book, we can see why the dividend per share has increased by 65% to 28p
Detail: Volumes up 9% to 5,913; Revenue up 16% to £1.92bn; PBT up 21% to £380m (4% ahead of Bloomberg consensus). Orderbook up 10% to £1.1bn. As ever with Redrow there is grumbling about the planning system holding volumes back, but with record volumes and profits these concerns are a sideshow to the main event, in our view. At 557p Redrow trades on a CY18 P/B of 1.3x (sector 1.4x) and offers a yield of 4.2% (sector 7.3%)

11:46 am
BE11:46am

As for the Help To Buy speculation .... yes, there's speculation.

BE11:46am

Simon French of Panmure has a good summary of where we are in the Times: https://www.thetim...y-market-zrnqrp3zx

BE11:47am

The Help to Buy scheme simply pours public money — £9billion of it and counting — into a housing market awash with private capital. In an economy where so much valuable investment fails to attract private capital, it is a vast waste of the state's resources.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Yep.

BE11:48am

With UK housing stock now worth in excess of £7trillion, it takes quite some myopia to conclude that the stretched public sector balance sheet needs to do more in this area.

By further inflating prices, Help to Buy also makes the basic problem of affordability even worse. Any reasonable review of the scheme would conclude that it has been like a fire engine attending a fire and choosing a tank full of kerosene to address the problem.

BE11:48am

Yep.

GBKrona @BE - so can the current HTB commitments to 2021 be pulled? Or is the speculation for renewal post-21?
11:50 am
BE11:50am

And here's UBS.

DRichi It took 5 years for the Gov to think that H2B increased prices rather than increased supply??? Hmmm.... no fooling them!
BE11:50am

We calculate that across England around 30% of private completions have made use of Help to Buy over recent years. In the listed space, the highest exposure is at Persimmon (nearly 60% of private completions) and lowest at Berkeley (sub-5%) and McCarthy & Stone (0 as all are retirement homes). Help to Buy has created a distinct advantage to the new-build sector, as it allows the purchase of a new-build property with only a 5% deposit. We believe purchasing with Help to Buy can be 15-20% cheaper than renting and up to 30% cheaper than purchasing a property with a 95% LTV mortgage.

BE11:51am

There are a number of dimensions on the potential impact on earnings: (1) Incentive costs: assuming 40% of completions have not incurred a 400-500bps incentive cost, we estimate a c2ppt margin impact or 10% of sector earnings; (2) Volume impact: industry estimates suggest a boost of 15% to industry volumes; (3) Pricing: this is likely to be the most challenging variable to estimate: while there is conflicting evidence of the boost from (HTB) on new-build pricing, we think it has been positive although note the constraining factor being mortgage valuations that likely put a cap on premiums.

Excel Developer @DRichi: I know, I'm fed up with Housing Ministers and their "learning curves"
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Bear in mind what we're talking about here, though .....

Flaneur Yet another David Cameron initiative....
BE11:52am

... it's a potential hard stop on HTB beyond 2021, or a temporary two-year extension of HTB into 2023 in a restricted form

chad_john So, potentially ending the support initiative for younger people to buy houses and probably putting taxes up. Should be a fun budget.
rw42 I wonder if the interesting question in govt circles is how do they now end H2B without also losing money on all the equity loans they've made on new build houses & flats!
BE11:53am

And that kind of timescale might matter to land-bank traders, but it shouldn't be a huge concern to equity investors. 2023!

11:53 am
BE11:54am

Back to UBS.

Stateless @RW42 Making house prices go up is a vote winner. So they will do that anyways
BE11:54am

The main adjustments variable is land pricing, which in theory should adjust downwards to restore margins and returns to compensate for the lack of HTB. However, we think it is unlikely that these will be fully able to offset, given land prices have already reduced as a % of house prices over recent years. Overall we expect a negative reaction to the sector, but believe low multiples (c8x unlevered P/E 2018E) already partly discount lower earnings on a sustainable basis.

chad_john @RW42 I'm sure Corbyn will spend his way out of it.
Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 2,381, down 57 (-2.34%), High: 2,461, Low: 2,373, Volume: 328.04k
11:54 am
Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 165.30, down 3.7 (-2.19%), High: 170.05, Low: 164.85, Volume: 5.17m
rw42 Well, options for new builds are relax earnings multiples limits on 95% mortgages or extend H2B - pretty sure anything else will lead to lower prices!
Stateless "relax earnings multiples limits on 95% " - bring back 2007!
BE11:55am

Berclay, down 1.8%, is .... what, 4% completions via HTB?

BE11:56am

And McCarthy's zero, of course .....

11:56 am
McCarthy & Stone PLC (MCS:LSE): Last: 111.80, down 2.9 (-2.53%), High: 115.00, Low: 110.80, Volume: 440.31k
BE11:57am

Attaching reasons to prices is quite often a complete nonsense, isn't it?

undefined
11:57 am
BE11:57am

Um, where were we?

BE11:57am

Quick bit of sellside. RBC's chucked in the towel on Inmarsat.

rw42 @Stateless :) not saying it's a good idea, but not sure any of the alternatives are acceptable either.. one thing worse in the public's eyes than throwing money at high earners to buy nicer flats, is to then lose money on it too!
Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 523.20, down 23.6 (-4.32%), High: 540.20, Low: 520.80, Volume: 1.43m
11:58 am
BE11:58am

RBC was very keen on the bid theory before it arrived, and kept the faith after it failed ......

Tom Dalgleish Maybe its already lost
BE11:59am

..... but they've been watching the skies:

BE11:59am

We believe Inmarsat has given up on wholesaling its fourth GX satellite (I5-F4) to the Chinese government. The satellite had been located at 117 East (over China) for several months while it conducted 'testing' with Inmarsat previously saying "the situation is highly commercially sensitive". However, with Inmarsat having been approached by a US buyer, satellite tracking now indicates it has moved to 11 East (over Europe/Africa). Management said on the 2Q call that there was a possible alternative use for the satellite, which we believe is most likely to be aviation/government. If this is the case it may lead to long term value creation, but we think the market is very unlikely to give the company credit (unless there is a substantial new contract announcement) given its track record to date in aviation. By comparison, we had estimated the value of a Chinese wholesale deal would have been an incremental c. £1 per share. If we assume the market had factored in a 30% probability of it being used in China, the downside risk is c.30p / 5%.

Flaneur @rw42 - thats how we got into this mess, isnt it?
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Also, they've flipflopped on Ligado, the US hybrid network thing that might or might not monkey around with military GPS.

BE12:00pm

In our earlier note (Per ardua as astra, 9 July) we argued that Ligado's amendment filing appeared to be backed by Government agencies and the GPS community (many of which had signed settlement agreements with Ligado). However, a review of the FCC submissions is deeply concerning with widespread concern over interference. Critically, many of the same GPS operators have cited the need to adhere to the so-called "1 dB IPC" test rather than an easier user-based test which Ligado prefers. The issue is highly contentious and technically complex, however we now believe the probability of FCC approval has significantly reduced.

BE12:01pm

So while Echostar might plausibly come back, which puts a floor under Inmarsat stock, the good news seems to be lacking right now.

12:01 pm
undefined
Blank canvas thanks BE for everything today.
rw42 @Flaneur - you picturing wiley coyote who's just about to stop peddling furiously over empty space?
BE12:02pm

That'll do us for today.

Soundbuy Cheers
Pharma HtB will become a vote looser as soon as the first batch of buyers find out they still owe the 20%, now with interest accumulating, and that demand for they house is lower because it is no longer eligible for HtB. Sob stories will be all over the media.
Excel Developer Cheers Bryce.
Tom Dalgleish Or the flotation device that requires pedalling
PandaMan fanx
BE12:03pm

No time to mention the weird situation at Scor: https://uk.reuters...ovea-idUKKCN1LK0JX

Excel Developer Last week Carney job speculation sent 10 UK Guilt yield up from 1.29 to 1.41
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

A sort-of hostile bid but not really.

Excel Developer *gilt*
GBKrona brill, thanks @BE. ROTR
BE12:05pm

No mention of Smiths either, which has edged up on an incremental scoop from Kleinmanator overnight: https://news.sky.c...8bn-offer-11489806

Tom Dalgleish Bonzer
BE12:06pm

But we're through midday and I have my actual job to be getting on with. So, ta for the comments.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Afternoon all.
